summary: more than 127,000 confirmed cases of 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1), including 800 deaths, were reported in mainland China. the distribution and characteristics of the confirmed cases in the initial phase of this pandemic in mainland China are largely unknown. the findings may have significant implications in the future pandemic preparedness and response. more than 214 countries and territories or communities had reported laboratory-confirmed cases of 2009 H1N1 including over 17798 deaths. the first case in mainland china was reported on may 11th, 2009. by march 31st 2010, more than 127,000 laboratorial confirmed cases were reported in the country. the study was conducted to investigate the geographic distribution of H1N1 infection in the 2009 pandemic as well as the risk factors for adverse patient outcome after initial H1N1 virus infection in mainland China. the study was therefore conducted to investigate the geographic distribution of H1N1 infection in the 2009 pandemic. median time from illness onset to hosptial discharge was 7 days. gender, time from illness onset to hospital admission, general symptoms and respiratory symptoms were all related to the outcome of the H1N1 patients. females patients had a lower porpotion of recovery (HR 0.9, 95%CI: 0.7–1.0), but the differnence was not statistically significant. the weekly reported new cases of confirmed H1N1 infection in different geographic regions of mainland China between May 7th to August 12th, 2009 are presented in Figure 2. appearance of respiratory symptoms but not gender were independent risk factors for adverse outcome. a confirmed case was defined as a person with influenza-like clinical manifestations and positive laboratory test for H1N1 virus. clinical outcome recovery was defined as resolution of symptoms as well as negative test results for H1N1 virus RNA for two consecutive days in throat swabs. potential risk factors assessed included gender, age, chronic pulmonary disease, time from onset to hospital admission, general symptoms, pharyngeal abnormality, tonsil abnormality, white blood cells count, complication and antiviral medication. the cases included in this study were those reported in the early phase of the epidemic between may 7th and august 16th, 2009. the case report form included: gender, age, chronic pulmonary disease history, time from onset to hospital admission, general symptoms (at least one of the following: dizziness, headache, chill, myalgia, arthralgia, weakness, anorexia, and/or conjunctivitis) the cumulative resolution rate was analyzed using Kaplan-Meier analysis and log-rank test. the subgroups were based on gender, time from onset to hospital admission, general symptoms or respiratory symptoms.
